HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE,. MD., JANUARY 30, 1924

Of all the tabulations of 1923
the "Best Similes" collection of the
_Vezv York Times, of December 23,
is the easiest reading. Tabulations
and summaries, at best, are boresome. Even a collection of excruciating of bon-mots becomes sickeningly sweet. There is nothing
more tiring than the earnest perusal of a Joke Book. Here, however, are a few lumps from the
Times' bowl of sugar:
He felt like the symptoms on a
medicine bottle—George Ade.
Noisy as iron waves splashing
and dashing on an iron ocean.-Anon.

THE COMING YEARS
(Read before Sigma Upsilon Literary Fraternity)
As our bright college days we journey through
To that one goal that ever stands in view,
That seems too distant, yet too near to us,
Who realize the time all-glorious
That comes but to the favored few,—the days
That part and send us on our several ways,
We cannot help but feel how time glides on,
How, e'er we know, our student-days are gone!
But oft our memories, dream-like, backward flow,
Bidding our cherished Alma Mater know
Our love for her grows dearer with the years,
A love that even this one regret endears:
That no man in his soul can e'er forget
We never can repay our life-long debt.
—Randolph Norwood,'24.

Sigma Upsilon, the Hopkins literary society, is to be in charge
of the assembly next week, which
is to be dedicated to the memory
of Sidney Lanier, the university's
greatest poet. This is in conjunction with the plans of the university's administrators in honoring
the birthday of the poet, which is
February 3.
Sidney Lanier, one of the leaders in American literary achievement, was for several years a lecturer at Johns Hopkins, and, although his services to the university were far reaching, he is little
known at Homewood now, especially among the undergraduates.
In allowing Sigma Upsilon the
privilege of presenting to the undergraduates a synopsis of his
work, it is believed that a more intimate touch can be given to the
proceedings. Under the leadership
of Dr. John C. French, the literary
fraternity has investigated the life
and works of Lanier, laying emphasis on his connections with the
Johns Hopkins University.
Randolph Norwood, president of
Sigma Upsilon, will have charge
of the meeting and will deliver a
short address. He will then introduce E. Paul Sylvester, who is to
give a summary of Lanier's life.
After. this several of his poetical
works will be rendered, among
which is included his "Hopkins
Ode."
Sigma Upsilon will endeavor to

have a placard of some sort placed
on the piece of ivy at Homewood,
which was transplanted from- Sidney Lanier's grave. Dr. French is,
at present, the only man at Hopkins who knows where to find this
plant and he is unwilling to disclose its location until a suitable
marker for it can be obtained. Norwood stated that it was Sigma Upsilon's intention to lead a drive
for a bronze tablet to mark this
spot. The only remembrance of
the great poet now existing is an
obscure bust in Gilman Hall.

TICKETS FOR BOWERY BALL
TO BE PUT ON SALE
FEBRUARY 6

The tickets for the Bowery
Ball which will be held on the night
of February 22 by the Class of
1925. have arrived from the printers and will be on sale immediately
after the mid-year exams. These
tickets may be procured only from
the members of the committee,
which consists of Gump, Urner,
Willison and Wales.
A new stunt in class affairs is
being introduced with the outlook
of decided success. Every man buying a ticket to the ball will be presented with a program and an original invitation to be sent to the
lady of his choice, asking her to attend in costume befitting the occasion. The invitation is well illustrated by striking sketches of representative costumes and scenes of
the ball. Fisher's orchestra will
supply the music for the entertainment. Other final arrangements are
being completed by the committee.

As the game proceeded a startling question entered the tired
brains of the players: what Was, after all, to be the factor which was
to determine the winner of the war? There were no goals to defend
and hence none to attain, so how was the victor to know when he
had won? Still the battle wore on, growing in intensity as the fires
of bitter jealousy burned into the souls of the warriors and yet no solution to the question was to be found. Longer and longer raged the
fray until one by one the contestants, gasping for air, lay them down
upon the frozen soil to pass into the world of slumber.

THE COMING YEARS
(Read before Sigma Upsilon Literary Fraternity)
As our bright college days we journey through
To that one goal that ever stands in view,
That seems too distant, yet too near to us,
Who realize the time all-glorious
That comes but to the favored few,—the days
That part and send us on our several ways,
We cannot help but feel how time glides on,
How, e'er we know, our student-days are gone!
But oft our memories, dream-like, backward flow,
Bidding our cherished Alma Mater know
Our love for her grows dearer with the years,
A love that even this one regret endears:
That no man in his soul can e'er forget
We never can repay our life-long debt.
—Randolph Norwood,'24.

Sigma Upsilon, the Hopkins literary society, is to be in charge
of the assembly next week, which
is to be dedicated to the memory
of Sidney Lanier, the university's
greatest poet. This is in conjunction with the plans of the university's administrators in honoring
the birthday of the poet, which is
February 3.
Sidney Lanier, one of the leaders in American literary achievement, was for several years a lecturer at Johns Hopkins, and, although his services to the university were far reaching, he is little
known at Homewood now, especially among the undergraduates.
In allowing Sigma Upsilon the
privilege of presenting to the undergraduates a synopsis of his
work, it is believed that a more intimate touch can be given to the
proceedings. Under the leadership
of Dr. John C. French, the literary
fraternity has investigated the life
and works of Lanier, laying emphasis on his connections with the
Johns Hopkins University.
Randolph Norwood, president of
Sigma Upsilon, will have charge
of the meeting and will deliver a
short address. He will then introduce E. Paul Sylvester, who is to
give a summary of Lanier's life.
After. this several of his poetical
works will be rendered, among
which is included his "Hopkins
Ode."
Sigma Upsilon will endeavor to

have a placard of some sort placed
on the piece of ivy at Homewood,
which was transplanted from- Sidney Lanier's grave. Dr. French is,
at present, the only man at Hopkins who knows where to find this
plant and he is unwilling to disclose its location until a suitable
marker for it can be obtained. Norwood stated that it was Sigma Upsilon's intention to lead a drive
for a bronze tablet to mark this
spot. The only remembrance of
the great poet now existing is an
obscure bust in Gilman Hall.

TICKETS FOR BOWERY BALL
TO BE PUT ON SALE
FEBRUARY 6

The tickets for the Bowery
Ball which will be held on the night
of February 22 by the Class of
1925. have arrived from the printers and will be on sale immediately
after the mid-year exams. These
tickets may be procured only from
the members of the committee,
which consists of Gump, Urner,
Willison and Wales.
A new stunt in class affairs is
being introduced with the outlook
of decided success. Every man buying a ticket to the ball will be presented with a program and an original invitation to be sent to the
lady of his choice, asking her to attend in costume befitting the occasion. The invitation is well illustrated by striking sketches of representative costumes and scenes of
the ball. Fisher's orchestra will
supply the music for the entertainment. Other final arrangements are
being completed by the committee.

Without the blatant formality of starting whistle the game began,
the contestants surging from one side of the court to the other as the
ball zig-zagged up and down the field, violent kicks, far stronger than
necessary, giving it the impetus of a cannon ball. Grim determination written on the face of each of the battlers shed an air of seriousness over the entire vicinity. Silently, though speedily, following
the ,leather-bound sphere the Owls were formidable antagonists for
the vicious Vultures, but they were doomed to fall.

As the game proceeded a startling question entered the tired
brains of the players: what Was, after all, to be the factor which was
to determine the winner of the war? There were no goals to defend
and hence none to attain, so how was the victor to know when he
had won? Still the battle wore on, growing in intensity as the fires
of bitter jealousy burned into the souls of the warriors and yet no solution to the question was to be found. Longer and longer raged the
fray until one by one the contestants, gasping for air, lay them down
upon the frozen soil to pass into the world of slumber.
